subtitle: thinking aloud
conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove hello and
welcome I'm Jeffrey Mishlove today we
are going to look at cultivating
psychokinesis from a unique perspective
because we'll be exploring the research
that I did with a talented psychokinetic
subject named Ted Owens as reported in
my book the pique man and with me in the
studio is Debra Lynn Katz who has an
unusual background as a researcher twice
the recipient of the Varco Lea award
from the International remote viewing
Association for an outstanding research
proposal she is also the president of
the international school of clairvoyance
she is a gifted psychic reader and a
remote viewer and the author of several
books including you are psychic
extraordinary psychic and freeing the
genie within welcome Debra thank you
Jeff great to be here it's good to be
with you and one of the reasons that we
set up this interview together is
because you've taken a particular
interest in the pique man and the
training of the pique man yes the first
time you talked to about Ted Owens I was
just fascinated and it seemed like such
an incredible documented case and you
did such a fantastic job writing the
whole book and really showing that this
wasn't just about taking a person who
had these experiences and believing him
but you really approach this from a very
intensive research perspective what was
that like for you well I worked with Ted
for 10 years from 1976 until his death
in 1987 I started that work as a
graduate student myself I was in my late
at the time and when the work began and
I was very eager and energetic I I first
heard about him when I visited Stanford
Research Institute he'll put off and
Russell Targ had invited me there to
learn remote viewing
as a matter of fact I did a remote
viewing session with them in February of
1976 and at the same time they had this
big file of papers and they said the
strange fellow Ted Owens has been
badgering us and and they said we know
he's got real abilities because he ended
a drought here in California for us and
Russell Targ said and I wrote back to
him and I told him that was a good
prediction and he wrote back to me and
he said hello
that was no prediction I caused it and
then they said but you know we're
getting into so much controversy with
our research with early Galler
which had been published in science or
nature magazine at the time they were
getting a lot of publicity that we can't
afford to have another controversial

mind taking this case on and and they

off and tire told me right off the bat
that there was this drought and I knew
about the drought it was going on and in

days of Owens say he would end the

which are very rare in the Bay Area and
and he said they'll be UFO sightings as

part of his signature and that's what

a student of parapsychology and and I
have to say it's hard for people to
appreciate what it was like back in the
1970s but it seemed as if the research
being done in parapsychology was going
to change the world there were two
things that look like they would change
the world one was computers and the
other to me was parapsychology and I can
look back and say yes computers did
since they changed the world the
Internet was just starting at that point
but progress in parapsychology has been
much slower and it's not that the
phenomenon aren't real Ted Owens
produced over a hundred and sixty
demonstrations of his abilities
two-thirds of which produced dramatic
results but it's more than people can

after his death I'm still talking about
it because I think you know people are
just starting to have the capacity to

regard to the human mind so can you give

with him a lot you were actually at

interesting in the book because you
would not just even after I had
and then you would set up a control

you were trying yes I did what I could

he worked with power blackouts
hurricanes tornadoes hot spells cold

Oh stations to to find out exactly what

they're easy to verify they're still on

some people were working-class people

day gathering of scientists to look at

and that that was a friendly response
and as far as being a loose cannon could

that assessment he was a very difficult

anybody who put themselves out the way
he did who said I can do this watch me
you know if you don't believe me just

is to treat everybody with respect
because you never know who might have

with him I was feeling fine at the time

Jeffrey I'm sorry I promise I will never

so one of the things I thought would be
